content.title: Temperature & Humidity Requirements for Bearded Dragons
content.content: Bearded dragons are ectothermic desert reptiles that require precise temperature gradients and low humidity for metabolic health. This guide provides evidence-based recommendations for thermal management based on Australian arid habitat conditions.

Proper thermal gradients enable behavioral thermoregulation°the ability to move between zones to maintain optimal body temperature. Multiple temperature zones are required, not a single ambient temperature.

content.text: Temperature Requirements by Zone:

content.content: Critical Requirement: Basking surface temperature of 100-110F is NON-NEGOTIABLE for proper digestion. Temperatures below 95F can cause food to rot in the digestive tract, leading to impaction and bacterial overgrowth.

For complete guidance on heating equipment options, thermostat configuration, and temperature monitoring tools, see our Temperature Monitoring Equipment Guide. The information below covers bearded dragon-specific heating requirements.
Heat source selection affects light spectrum quality, thermal penetration depth, and safety. Halogen bulbs provide the most naturalistic solar-quality heat with visible light output.

content.text: Heat Source Comparison:

content.content: Recommended Setup: 75-100W halogen flood for primary basking + optional deep heat projector for ambient warmth. Thermostat-controlled for safety and temperature regulation.
Thermostatic control prevents thermal burns and lethal overheating. Unregulated heat sources are a leading cause of reptile mortality.

Probe Placement: Position thermostat probe at basking surface level, 2-3 inches from center of basking spot. Set target temperature 5-10°F below desired surface temp to account for radiant heat. Verify with infrared thermometer.
Safety Critical: NEVER operate heat sources without thermostatic control. A failed bulb or malpositioned fixture can create lethal hot spots exceeding 150F within minutes.
Accurate temperature measurement requires multiple tools and measurement points. Single thermometers provide insufficient data for proper thermal gradient verification.

content.text: Measurement Equipment:

Place at basking height on warm side

Notoriously inaccurate°do not rely on these

content.content: Best Practice: Check temperatures at 3 points daily: basking surface (infrared gun), warm side ambient (probe), cool side ambient (probe). Record in log for 1-2 weeks after setup to identify fluctuations.
Bearded dragons are desert species requiring LOW humidity. Excessive humidity causes respiratory infections, skin infections, and bacterial overgrowth.

content.text: Humidity Targets:

rows: Brief increase only during active shed

content.content: Common Mistake: Many keepers over-humidify bearded dragon enclosures. These are DESERT animals. No misting required. High humidity is harmful, not beneficial.
Temperature requirements vary slightly by age and brumation status. Adult dragons may brumate (winter dormancy) with temperature reductions.
Brumation Note: Not required for pet dragons. Only attempt with healthy adults after veterinary consultation. Juveniles and sick animals should NEVER brumate.

content.text: Temperature Problems & Solutions:

rows: Raise bulb or decrease wattage, add thermostat
Move heat to one end only, ensure cool retreat
Add ventilation, reduce heat source wattage
Room temperature high, heat not turning off
Ensure heat sources turn off at night, increase ventilation

content.content: Equipment failures and power outages require contingency plans. Bearded dragons can tolerate temporary temperature drops better than overheating.

rows: Wrap enclosure with blankets, use heat packs (external)
Open enclosure, increase ventilation, cool room
Turn off heat, open enclosure, mist lightly
Immediate can be lethal within 30 minutes

content.content: Emergency Preparation: Always keep spare bulbs, backup thermostat, and hand warmers on hand. Test backup equipment monthly to ensure functionality.
